												What would be considered a truly innovative and immersive evolution in the Resident Evil universe by some, an abomination by others, Resident Evil 5 is what you make of it.  I was one of the die-hards from the old school series that initially frowned upon this new "advancement" in the series, but what I looked down my nose at back in 2009, I can now reminisce upon with affection.  Sure it may not be a true traditional survival horror game, but let's take a look at what it did right.  We are re-united with franchise favorite Chris Redfield, bringing in the old-school fans, and we are introduced to Sheva, who is actually portrayed as a strong woman with character and proves to be a solid partner.  We have a new co-op dynamic that we had never seen before in this form, making it honestly approachable to fresh blood, bringing new fans to the series.  With a solid storyline and an impressive amount of collectibles to find, upgrades to weapons and armor, and the classic "Mercenaries" mode you'll find an overall enjoyable experience.  I personally still find the game visually beautiful, the voice acting solid, and the controls are ace.  It's not something we initially accepted as a great game, but looking back and re-playing it brings me an immense amount of happiness.  Sure, Excellea was an awful character, the portrayal of Jill was pretty terrible, the demise of one of my favorite characters was the worst...but I still smile when I play.  And I think at its core it has its heart in the right place, and that's what's important.

Recently I've bought Resident Evil 6 to play with and was more than pleased with the game mechanics, cutscenes, voice acting and more action-orentied gameplay (with both tight and fluid keyboard and mouse controls) than classic chapters of Resident Evil. I played all the classic chapters on PC and PSX and always loved the franchise, either it was a horror-survival or action-survival game. After beating Resident Evil 6, getting all the achievements, all skills and all of other stuff, I wanted to try the preceding chapter, so I bought Resident Evil 5 second time, now both the main game and the gold edition add-on to have this game with Steamworks support. Turned out that the game is actually better than sequel and more fun too, I've beaten the game on all four difficulties with S-rank, I bought and upgraded almost all weapons, now heading to get all those achivements. Back to the game - the camera is under your full control, no annoying "director" in your way like in RE6, way less QTE moments but they look awkward on keyboard. You cannot walk while shoot (remember - I've already played Dead Space and Resident Evil 6 at this moment) but the devs were taking it into account so it works really well. The only drawback is your AI partner, which can be pretty annoying on Professional difficulty - you'll be hearing "Shevaaa!" a lot as she will die from the sunbeam in 4th chapter most of the time. Damn, it pisses me off, believe me. Oh, and it consumes my ammo - shame on you, Capcom, it's mine - get your dirty hands off it! And QTE moments - while RE6 has a ton of it, they feels ok - good luck becaming a pro in pressing F+V in RE5. All of this cons were addressed and corrected in RE6 but still RE5 is better game almost in any way. Maybe the multiplayer section and the mercenaries is better in RE6. The major difference is that the RE5 is more a game rather than "playable movie" style of RE6. I suggest you to buy both games and play RE6 first. The game is more than good. It's not the best way to follow the games' storylines but I played this way and after completing both games it doesn't really matter which one came first. And then play RE5, which is awesome. If you tend to play with the gamepad I suggest you to play Resident Evil 4 which is also a very good game and, as they say, better than both RE5 and RE6, but suffering from bad keyboard and mouse controls support, even in HD re-release, and I don't possess the Xbox controller. 												Quick rundown: Resident Evil 5 continues the evolution of the Resident Evil series into more action than horror. If you’ve played Resident Evil 4 and wanted better controls, better graphics, and more gunfire, you’ll enjoy RE 5. They’ve also refined the combat system so you don’t spend as much time knifing people lying on the ground because ammo is a lot less of a problem this time around (overall). You still run out of ammo in the middle of some missions, but you can quit and reload, getting access to your stash. Note that RE 5 is the kind of game you where you can keep load and replay specific chapters to grind for money and ammo. If you have a co-op partner the game is much more fun since the entire campaign can be played with a friend (or a stranger). Games for Windows Live has been stripped out of the Steam version by the way, but it’s not perfectly done.The game’s story follows Chris Redfield as he battles his way through various hostile environments in Africa with his new partner Sheva. Chris is an officer in the BSAA, investigating the apparent use of bioweapons in the area, and by bioweapon I don’t mean Ebola or Super Aids. 												It may say I have spent around 9 hours on steam. But I have around 80~ hours on Xbox360.Let me start this off by saying my review may be a little biased. I have played every resident evil available to the public. I was raised on resident evil. I played my first at age eight. I have loved them all. My favorites being resident evil 3, 4, and outbreak files 1 and 2. I love zombies, you love zombies? resident evil 5 is not a "zombie game" it's barely even a "biohazard" game. the majority of the enemies you fight will resemble people, will act like people, will fight like people. And the "zombie" aspects of these "people" are very minimal. but still, it is a Resident Evil. it is co-op, has collectables, money, weapon upgrades, a decent amount of weapons, the herbs we know and love, and character skins. Fun stuff, endless hours of fun.Why is this review negative? Because this game might have the absolute worst AI, worst storyline, worst boss fights, and best cover based shooter atmosphere a resident evil game has ever had.AI: Example; (those that played the game will understand, if you have not, google the key figures) After aquiring the second machine-gun and leaving the warehouse where you are greeted with the ocean and two abandoned half-sunken ships. I began by destroying one of the wall mines and moving forward, Sheva on "cover" with her pistol out. She ran ahead of me into the arms of the first spawning enemy in the area and she didn't fire a single bullet and was grabbed. I saved her and the enemy was in a wounded position. I moved in to punch the target and Sheva kicked him, subsequently hitting me and knocking me to the ground. I got up and began to knife the downed target. During this time Sheva shot me three times in the back and reloaded. we moved forward and I dispatched every enemy while sheva fired six more bullets into my back. We approached the three dog fight. She did not fire at a single dog and was hit four times by dogs. I killed all of them with my shotgun. I set sheva to assualt and she switched to her machine-gun. she proceeded to fire on a crossbow wielding enemy standing above the dog spawn. the man fell to the ground and she proceeded to fill this man with 30 machine-gun rounds. I decided to back-track and search for items we may have missed. I found an herb and a first-aid spray. I gave her the first aid spray to hold onto. she immediately used it. (Me at 100% health, her at 75% health)  I sighed and we moved on to a back side area protected by a wall-mine but gave access to the area via ladder. I climbed the ladder and hopped down to the area. Beginning to loot i was greeted with an explosive directly behind me and I was thrown forward. Behind my surprised ♥♥♥ was a bleeding out and dying Sheva. I proceeded to Ctrl+alt+del and quit the game. This isn't the first and won't be the last time the AI has disappointed me.(Spoilers)Storyline: Long story short. Series of boss fights with a dozen handouts where you are "saved" in cutscene all while looking for your BFF, Bio-weapons, Scientist-Mc-man, Super Wesker, ♥♥♥♥-Mc-gee and Tri-Cell, I mean umbrella2.0. you find Bio-weapons, you find scientist-mc-man(who becomes a bio-weapon, you find ♥♥♥♥-mc-gee(she becomes a bio-weapon), you find Super Wesker(he was already a bio-weapon), and you find BFF(who has a bio-weapon in her ♥♥♥♥) using the power of friendship you find Super Wesker again, he becomes even more super then you get on a plane, and Quick-Time-Event simulator happens. Then you fight Super Super wesker the Meat-Tornado in a volcano, punch a rock, and save the world. Resident Evil/Biohazard is a game series in which you fight the nightmares of Man-kind. Bio-terrorist/weapons that turn the living into the dead, and the dead into the undead or worse. Here I feel like I'm fighting people.. all the time. Resident Evil should stick to zombies, not this crazed axe wielding human ♥♥♥♥. >Should I get this game? Yes. It's a good game. Well optimized, difficulties, collectables, upgrades, co-op, PvP, etc. It's a solid game. But do not play this game alone. AI will make you hate this game.

												Death by reloadingRE5 is a great game spoiled by atrocious controls. I mean the worst ever. These are the main problems: You can’t move while reloading, aiming, or shooting; instead you become rooted to the spot and therefore hopelessly vulnerable to attack. When aiming the sight is often (although, oddly, not always) wrenched away from the point already centred so you have to find your target again. And you can’t jump or crouch unless prompted. What the hell is that all about? Also the AI is pretty poor. Sheva gets in the way more often than not. The UI looks like something out of the 90s and is clunky to say the least. And you can’t access the inventory during gameplay (although I understand the reasoning behind this it is frustrating at times). So what is there to like? Well it looks amazing. The graphics are among the best I’ve ever seen, with particularly impressive character models and animations. And, controls aside, the gameplay is enjoyable, with a good selection of environments, some pretty tough bosses, and a range of simple but enjoyable puzzles to solve. Ammo is often scarce so you have to be more thoughtful about your approach to the combat than in many games. Overall it’s a top-flight game marred only but it’s poorly designed controls and interface. Sadly these are so bad I can only give it 3 out of 5, which is a real shame.3/5
